Acrtually, one of the reasons the waldo canyon fire was so fierce is the very active fire suppression activities over the last century.  Large numbers of people living in the WUI notwithstanding.  Ponderosa forests should be wide spread open areas with some large trees.  This typically allows low heat fires to sweep through periodically and keep the brush and such down.  Active fire suppression has crowded those forests, Ten years of dry weather has weakened even the "giants" and the forest has been ripe for a burn for sometime because of this.  We do understand this now, but are stopped by inactivity and financial considerations of planning burn offs, chaining out open spaces, etc that can lessen the damage, a utility department that will not allow planned burns on the watershed (well now we get to see what an unplanned one will do)  and again money to remove the dead and dying that helped fuel this monster.

So it's hotter, that's all, Robert.  No need to over think it.  I've lived for 64 years and I've never seen anything like this. Is it part of human induced global warming?  I think so from my perspective.  I've noticed the light change..I'm an artist.  I've noticed plants, birds and insects disappearing and others getting more pesty, like deer, ticks and lyme.  I've noticed the water is way dirtier where I live..the Chesapeake Bay.  The water gets hotter now..it can't breathe.  I notice that there are tons more people EVERYWHERE I go. And the worst is the air.  It is often clogged up in the Chesapeake, made far worse by the smog from the west getting bottled up here.  The weather patterns have changed splitting fronts up over the region, with less rain.  I mulch.  It helps. The caps are melting, and we are not getting any positive benefits from that, except more violent weather than I have EVER recalled.  So I'm only 64, but why should the sky be greyish white when it should be blue? That is not natural. Even in the winter it is too often like this.

The PATRIOT Act was no dramatic departure from existing legislation. Indeed, its key provisions were incorporated from an anti-terrorism measure that had been passed by Congress and signed into law by former President Bill Clinton five years earlier: the "Anti-Terrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996," which was a response to Timothy McVeigh's April 1995 bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City that killed 175 innocent people.

This 1996 Act contained a number of key provisions to combat terrorism, but the ones that immediately inspired the formation of a leftist coalition against the legislation were three particular provisions that: (a) made it a criminal offense to provide "material support" or "expert advice or assistance" to terrorist groups; (b) allowed prosecutors to use secret evidence in terrorism cases; and (c) authorized the U.S. Secretary of State, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Attorney General to jointly designate organizations as terrorist groups based upon available evidence. The most influential civil-liberties voices in the United States alleged that with the passage of the 1996 bill, the rights and freedoms of all Americans were under assault by a government that was seeking not only empire abroad, but totalitarian control at home.
Now you can call this what you want but you are wrong and I am right. This is the patriot act and it was signed into law by Bill Clinton.

The recent Vanity Fair article speculates that Romney's IRA (and, presumably, those of his Bain colleagues) received common stock of Bain acquisition targets priced at a very low basis. The stock presumably was re-valued over time. If tax law was followed appropriately and valuations were fair, congratulations to Mr. Romney and his Bain colleagues.

At the same time, these IRA gains raise the possibility that Romney and Bain Capital employs also made hefty personal gains from transactions which resulted in the loss of jobs and employee pension plans. And because IRAs allow profits to be reinvested tax free until retirement is reached, original gains continue to be reinvested. None of this, of course, would win Mr. Romney much support among middle-income and lower-income voters.

Those were my exact thoughts. I was having trouble putting it that succinctly. "At this point...the worst candidate in my lifetime."

Hi Ken - You make a common error. The high tax rates you recall from the 50's and 60's were MARGINAL rates. They only applied to income above a certain value. So if you are wealthy, your overall tax rate will always be less than the marginal rate you pay.

But that's what we need today--much higher marginal rates to encourage the Rich from taking their money out of their corps who could then pay better wages to people who would spend the money and improve the business climate. It would also discourage the rampant speculation that has serious impaired the world's economy.
Yeah, I wonder, too.  But he's the one running for president, so he's the one that should be scrutinized.

"Those returns also reveal that he paid a lot of taxes — 36 percent of his income in 1960, 37 percent over the whole period. This was in part because, as one report at the time put it, he 'seldom took advantage of loopholes to escape his tax obligations'." --- Krugman about George Romney.

The tax rate for such high incomes was in the neighborhood of 50 percent or more in the 1960's, so George Romney must have taken advantage of some loopholes and tax write-offs to get his rate down to 36 percent. Of course, he was legally entitled to them then, and they were not nearly so generous or inane, like the pseudo-capital gains tax that many of the rich, including son Mitt, pay today.

But so much has changed in 44 years. Then, we had a thriving automotive industry, were a global manufacturing center, had an education system that was the envy of the rest of the world, and a large and resilient middle class. Large companies, such as American Motors at the time, provided generous pensions to their workers --- the result of union bargaining, lest we forget. The one place where we fell behind even then was in medical care. After Truman failed to get single-payer ("socialized") medicine passed, no further serious effort was made until Clinton's administration, and now we have an unnecessarily complicated program.

As for off-shored investments and secret bank accounts, I wonder how many Senators, Representatives, and Administration bigwigs have done the same thing as Mitt Romney?

Thanks for the clarification Charlie - this is a common misperception that the media, including the NY Times don't usually take time to explain.  For those making more than $250,000, only the amount OVER $250,000 will be taxed at a higher rate.  The first $250,000 would continue to be taxed at the lower rate.
And this is why all the so-called Bush tax cuts must end at the end of this year.

Not so sure about that.  When people have mixed income sources (earned and investment income), it's not clear which income source gets the preferential rate.  If your combined income is $270K, of which $100K is dividends, do those dividends get taxed at 15% or 42%, or is it proportional that some earned income and some dividends get taxes at the lower rate.

This article errs when it says Obama is, "calling for a one-year extension of the Bush-era tax cuts for people making less than $250,000 a year."

The first $250,000 of everyone's income will receive the more favorable treatment. A person earning $260,000, for example, will see higher taxes only on that last $10,000 of income.
